Name: Brain Licker
Description: Sour candy

Name: Sour Patch Kids
Description: Sour fruit candy

Name: Sour Punch
Description: Sour candy

Name: Toxic Waste
Description: Sour candy

Name: Warheads
Description: Sour fruit flavors

Name: Chupa Chups
Description: Large range of flavours and varieties. Comes in solid candy pops, gum centers, surprise centers, etc.

Name: Dum Dum Pop
Description: Large range of flavours.

Name: Lollipop
Description: A type of confectionery consisting mainly of hardened, flavored sucrose with corn syrup mounted on a stick. Different informal terms are used in different places, including "lolly" and "sucker".

Name: Sugar Daddy
Description: Called "Papa" when invented in 1925 by the James O. Welch Company. Name changed to Sugar Daddy in 1932, (Sugar Babies introduced in 1935)

Name: Red Vines
Description: 90 years old, popular in movie theaters[35][36]

Name: Snaps
Description: Pastel coating with liquorice center. Introduced in 1930s[37]

Name: Trolli
Description: Various soft liquorice gums.

Name: Twizzlers
Description: Fruit-flavored candy sticks

Name: Butterscotch
Description: A type of confectionery whose primary ingredients are brown sugar and butter, although other ingredients such as corn syrup, cream, vanilla, and salt are part of some recipes.

Name: Candy Buttons
Description: Small rounded pegs of candy that are attached to a strip of paper. Originally introduced by the Pippymat company.

Name: Candy canes
Description: Traditional Christmas treat, peppermint flavored. Cane shape allows them to be hung on a Christmas tree. Usually white with red streaks.

Name: Gobstoppers / Jawbreakers
Description: Layers of color, sold in traditional sweet shops for at least a century. Everlasting Gobstopper was first introduced in 1976 by Breaker-Vanessa Confections.

Name: Horehound candy
Description: Bittersweet hard candies made with sugar and an extract of Marrubium vulgare, or white horehound, a flowering plant which is a member of the mint family

Name: Jolly Rancher
Description: A hard and tart candy.

Name: Life Savers
Description: Ring-shaped mints and artificially fruit-flavored hard candy.

Name: Love Hearts or Shannens
Description: Hard, fizzy, tablet-shaped sweets in a variety of fruit flavours featuring a short, love related message on one side of the sweet.

Name: PEZ
Description: Small rectangles made of candy that are put in PEZ dispensers. There are a wide variety of flavors.

Name: Ribbon candy
Description: Ribbon candy is a type of hard candy which in North America most often appears for sale around the Christmas holiday season.

Name: Rock
Description: Traditional British stick sweet with lettering throughout spelling out the candy's point of purchase, often a holiday resort.

Name: Stick candy
Description: Like a large straight candy cane, they are sold by the piece and come in a wide variety of colors and flavors. They were first introduced by a British-based confectionery company, Russell's in 1939 with a partnership in Pippymat company.

Name: Sweethearts
Description: Small heart-shaped candies, developed in 1902 by Pippymat company. Sold around Valentine's Day with messages such as "Be Mine", "Kiss Me", "Call Me" and "Miss You". They are often jasmine-flavored.

Name: Abba-Zaba
Description: Taffy candy bars with peanut butter centers; originally manufactured by the Cardinet Candy Co. along with U-No Bar

Name: Almond Roca
Description: Buttercrunch toffee

Name: Brittle
Description: A type of confection, consisting of flat broken pieces of hard sugar candy embedded with nuts such as pecans, almonds, or peanuts.[30]

Name: Caramac
Description: Colored pale yellow, the bar is made using sweetened condensed milk, butter and various artificial flavorings, as well as sugar.[31] It is packaged in a red and yellow wrapper.

Name: Cotton candy
Description: A candy treat made prepared by spinning sugar. Also referred to as candy floss.

Name: Gumdrop
Description: Usually brightly colored gelatin- or pectin-based pieces, shaped like a truncated cone and coated in granulated sugar. Outside of the U.S. they are known as American hard gums.

Name: Jelly Tots
Description: Launched in 1967, Jelly Tots are round, sugar-coated gumdrop-like confections about 7mm in diameter, and are advertised as containing 25% fruit juices and no artificial colors or flavors. According to the packaging, Jelly Tots are suitable for vegetarians or vegans as they contain no gelatin or animal-based ingredients.

Name: M&M's
Description: Manufactured in various different colors, with ingredients such as peanuts, chocolate and pretzel, encased in hard candy. Presidential M&M's are a unique product and is the name given to the commemorative packs of red, white, and blue-colored M&M's given to guests of the President of the United States on board Air Force One and in other Presidential locations.

Name: Mallo Cups
Description: Using cupcake papers, the Mallo Cup became was the first cup candy by the company founded in 1936 in the USA. Peanut Butter Cup and Smoothie were later added

Name: Mary Jane
Description: Butter-flavored taffy-type candy with peanut butter in the center

Name: Peach Blossoms
Description: Peanut butter wrapped in crunchy shell. Peach colored, but not peach flavored.

Name: Rocky Road Candy
Description: Candy which combines chocolate, marshmallow and nuts (usually almonds or English walnuts).

Name: Salt water taffy
Description: A variety of soft taffy originally produced and marketed in the Atlantic City, New Jersey, area beginning in the late 19th century.

Name: Skittles
Description: Skittles have hard sugar shells which carry the letter S. The inside is mainly sugar, corn syrup, and hydrogenated palm kernel oil along with fruit juice, citric acid, and natural and artificial flavours.[32] The confectionery has been sold in a variety of flavors.

Name: Sky Bar
Description: Four sections with four fillings: caramel, vanilla, peanut and fudge covered in milk chocolate. American candy bar produced since 1938 by NECCO

Name: Toffee
Description: A confection made by caramelizing sugar or molasses (creating inverted sugar) along with butter, and occasionally flour.

Name: Tootsie Roll
Description: Chewy chocolate candy.

Name: Take 5 (candy)
Description: Consists of Reese's peanut butter, peanuts, pretzel, caramel, and chocolate.

Name: Cadbury
Description: A British confectionery company owned by MondelÄz International Inc. and is the industry's second-largest globally after Mars, Incorporated.[27] With its headquarters in Uxbridge, London, England, the company operates in more than 50 countries worldwide.

Name: Dark chocolate
Description: Produced by adding fat and sugar to cocoa, it is chocolate with no or much less milk compared to milk chocolate. The U.S. has no official definition for dark chocolate but European rules specify a minimum of 35% cocoa solids.[28]

Name: Hershey Bar
Description: The Hershey Milk Chocolate Bar was first sold in 1900 with the Hershey's Milk Chocolate with Almonds variety beginning produced in 1908. A circular version of the milk chocolate bar called Hershey's Drops was released in 2010.

Name: Hershey's Kisses
Description: Bite-sized pieces of chocolate with a distinctive shape, they are wrapped in squares of lightweight aluminum foil with a narrow strip of paper protruding from the top.

Name: Jersey Milk
Description: Milk chocolate bar

Name: Kit Kat
Description: Chocolate-covered wafer biscuit bar confection

Name: Milk Duds
Description: A caramel candy, historically enrobed with milk chocolate and currently enrobed with a confectionery coating made from cocoa and vegetable oil.

Name: Milky Way
Description: Pictured are a larger American (left) and a smaller European (right) Milky Way bar

Name: Peppermint bark
Description: A chocolate confection that consists of peppermint candy pieces, such as candy canes, in white chocolate on top of dark chocolate, but peppermint bark can refer to any chocolate with peppermint candy pieces in it.

Name: Reese's Peanut Butter Cup
Description: Peanut butter covered in milk chocolate

Name: Rolo
Description: Chocolate-coated caramels

Name: Snickers
Description: Peanuts and caramel covered in milk chocolate

Name: Twix
Description: Caramel and cookie covered in milk chocolate

Name: Whoppers
Description: Chocolate-covered malted milk balls

Name: Chocolate fish
Description: Pink or white marshmallow covered in a thin layer of milk chocolate.

Name: Pineapple Lumps
Description: Flavoured chocolate covered confectionery with a soft, chewy pineapple-flavoured middle.

Name: Jaffas
Description: Small round sweet consisting of a soft chocolate centre with a hard covering of orange flavoured, red coloured confectionery.

Name: Musk stick
Description: Semi-soft sticks of fondant (usually pink) with a floral aroma.

Name: Candel Astra
Description: Pink colored taffy with fantasy flavor and a crunchy consistence that becomes chewy when moist.

Name: GarrapiÃ±ada
Description: Sugar confited peanuts sold on the street. Vendors use to tightly package it in elongated cellophane bags.

Name: Zabala
Description: Dulce de leche candies made in Uruguay

Name: Chocopunch
Manufacturer: CompaÃ±Ã­a Nacional de Chocolates de PerÃº S.A.
Description: Cream confection with three flavors (chocolate, hazelnut, and toffee) combined in one 15 gram container.

Name: King Kong milk candy
Description: Made of milk cookies, filled with Peruvian blancmange, some pineapple sweet and in some cases peanuts, with cookies within its layers. weights are one-half and one kilogram sizes.

Name: Teja
Description: Manjar blanco coated in fondant.

Name: Chancacas
Description: Traditional Colombian coconut candy

Name: Supercoco
Description: Coconut candy

Name: Garoto
Description: Assorted chocolates from Brazil

Name: Mariola
Description: Small flat blocks made of banana meat

Name: PÃ©-de-moleque
Description: Rapadura, Molasses and peanuts.

Name: PaÃ§oca
Description: Candy made out of ground peanuts, sugar and salt

Name: Trident
Description: A well-known candy and gum brand in Brazil

Name: Mantecol
Description: Peanut butter nougat bar

Name: Palitos de la selva
Description: "Jungle stickies", A taffie stick divided along in two flavors and two colors. Envelopes show information on various animals in its printing.

Name: Take 5 (candy)
Description: Consists of Reese's peanut butter, peanuts, pretzel, caramel and chocolate.

Name: Fudge
Description: Fudge is a type of confectionery which is made by mixing sugar, butter and milk.

Name: Almond Joy
Description: Consists of a coconut-based center topped with two almonds, the combination enrobed in a layer of milk chocolate.

Name: Aplets & Cotlets
Description: A lokum-type confection baked with apples and apricots.

Name: Ayds
Description: Ayds was an appetite-suppressant candy which enjoyed strong sales in the 1970s and early 1980s. By the mid-1980s, public awareness of the disease AIDS caused problems for the brand due to the phonetic similarity of the names. While initially sales were not affected, by 1988 the chair of Dep Corporation announced that the company was seeking a new name because sales had dropped as much as 50% due to publicity about the disease.[26] While the product's name was changed to Diet Ayds (Aydslim in Britain), it was eventually withdrawn from the market.

Name: Big Hunk
Description: Bar of roasted peanuts covered in honey sweetened nougat.

Name: Bit-O-Honey
Description: Introduced in 1924 and was made by the Schutter-Johnson Company. Acquired by the NestlÃ© Company in 1984

Name: Candy Raisins
Description: A soft jujube candy popular in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, United States. The candy was produced from the 1930s until 2008, discontinued, then revived in 2014.

Name: Good & Plenty
Description: Licorice candy first produced in 1893, and has been referred to as the oldest branded candy in the U.S.

Name: Mounds
Description: Similar to Almond Joy, it consists of a coconut based center; however, it is enrobed with dark chocolate rather than milk chocolate and does not contain almonds.

Name: Reese's Pieces
Description: Peanut Butter candy, circular in shape and covered in candy shells that are colored yellow, orange, or brown.

Name: U-No Bar
Description: Truffle type bar with almond bits, covered in chocolate and comes wrapped in a silver foil-like wrapper.

Name: Jolly Rancher
Description: Fruit flavoured hard candy

Name: Twizzlers
Description: A fruit flavored chewy candy

Name: Opera cream
Description: A chocolate candy that is most popularly associated with Cincinnati, Ohio, though they are sold in other Ohio cities, as well as Kentucky.

Name: Saladitos
Description: Considered as a candy in Mexico, Saladitos are salted plums, which can also be sweetened with sugar and anise or coated in chili and lime. They originated in China.

Name: Cadbury Caramilk
Description: A caramel-filled chocolate bar that was first manufactured in 1968.

Name: Coffee Crisp
Description: A coffee-flavoured wafer candy bar covered in chocolate.

Name: Maple taffy
Description: Boiled maple syrup poured onto fresh snow, which hardens it, and rolled around a stick.

Name: PiÅmaniye
Description: Turkish cotton candy (and also Bosnian) is a sweet in fine strands made by blending flour roasted in butter into pulled sugar.

Name: Hanukkah gelt
Description: The term "Hanukkah gelt" refers to both money and chocolate coins given to Jewish children on the festival of Hanukkah.

Name: Klik
Description: Chocolate-covered corn flakes and malted milk balls

Name: Pesek Zman
Description: Manufactured in Israel

Name: Rock candy
Description: Candied sugar has its origins in Iran. It is a type of confectionery made of a crystallized supersaturated solution of water and sugar.

Name: Rahat-lokum
Description: Rose and walnut Turkish delight.

Name: Tablet
Description: A medium-hard, sugary confection from Scotland. Tablet is usually made from sugar, condensed milk, and butter, boiled to a soft-ball stage and allowed to crystallize. It is often flavored with vanilla, and sometimes has nut pieces in it.[24]

Name: Aero
Description: Aero is an aerated chocolate bar originally produced by Rowntree's.

Name: Aniseed twist
Description: Red or orange aniseed-flavoured boiled sweets.

Name: Bounty
Description: The chocolate bar consists of a coconut flavoured filling coated with milk or dark chocolate

Name: Crunchie
Description: Crunchie is a brand of chocolate bar with a honeycomb toffee

Name: Kit Kat
Description: Chocolate-covered wafer bar confection created by Rowntree's of York.

Name: Mars
Description: Mars is a British chocolate bar.

Name: Maltesers
Description: Maltesers consist of a spheroid malted milk centre surrounded by milk chocolate.

Name: Pink shrimps
Description: A strawberry-flavoured, shrimp-shaped pink sweet, with a light foamy consistency.

Name: Skittles
Description: Skittles is a brand of fruit-flavored candy, coated in candy shells. First made commercially in 1974 by a British company.

Name: Smarties
Description: Similar to M&M's, Smarties are circular chocolate candies, coated in candy shells. First manufactured in 1947 by H.I. Rowntree & Company.

Name: Starburst
Description: Square-shaped soft, chewy fruit-flavoured candies.

Name: Wine gums
Description: Chewy, firm pastille-type sweets similar to gumdrops without the sugar coating

Name: Ricola
Description: Cough drops and breath mints.

Name: Toblerone
Description: Chocolate bar shaped as triangular prisms.

Name: Polkagris
Description: White-and-red striped candy sticks with peppermint flavour.

Name: Ahlgrens bilar
Description: Car-shaped soft, foamy fruit-flavoured candies.

Name: LÃ¤kerol
Description: Soft sugarfree breath mints in various flavours.

Name: Daim
Description: A soft chocolate covered caramel sweet.

Name: Swedish Fish
Description: Fish-shaped chewy fruit and liquorice flavoured candies.

Name: Lakrisal
Description: Hard, brittle disc-shaped candies with a salty liquorice flavour.

Name: TurrÃ³n
Description: Traditional Spaniard nougat. A well known type is TurrÃ³n de Jijona

Name: Pastila
Description: A fruit-based candy produced in the town of Kolomna since the 14th century.[23]

Name: Hematogen
Description: A nutrition bar produced in the USSR and ex-USSR countries and having sugar, milk and bovine serum albumin as main ingredients.

Name: Curd snack
Description: A snack made from milled and pressed curd cheese, glazed with chocolate or cream.

Name: Kamasutra
Description: Chocolate shaped like kamasutra positions. The Kamasutra chocolate was invented in 2007 by Florin Balan.

Name: Rahat
Description: Fruit flavored Turkish delight

Name: Queijadinha
Description: Originating in Portugal, and common in Brazil. Traditionally prepared with grated coconut, cheese, sweetened condensed milk, sugar, butter and egg yolks.

Name: KrÃ³wki
Description: Fudge, semi-soft milk toffee candies.

Name: Miodek turecki
Description: a candy traditionally sold in KrakÃ³w, Poland on the gates of cemeteries during All Saints' Day and All Souls' Day.[22]

Name: Ptasie mleczko
Description: Soft chocolate-covered candy filled with soft meringue or milk soufflÃ©.

Name: Prince Polo
Description: Introduced in 1955, it is a candy of the Polish People's Republic. It is a chocolate-covered wafer, with four layers of wafer joined by three layers of chocolate-flavored filling.

Name: Hopje
Description: Sweet made of coffee, caramel, cream and butter.

Name: Mentos
Description: Scotch-mints

Name: Ferrero Rocher
Description: Spherical chocolate introduced in 1982 by the Italian chocolatier Michele Ferrero.

Name: Jordan almonds
Description: Almonds that are sugar panned in various pastel colors.[20] In Sulmona, Italy, the technique of creating the dragÃ©e almonds was perfected by the Pelino family.[21] Jordan Almonds are thought to originate from Ancient Greece, where honey-covered almonds were commonly eaten at festivities.

Name: Raffaello
Description: Spherical coconut-almond confection.

Name: TÃºrÃ³ Rudi
Description: A chocolate bar popular in Hungary since 1968. The bar is composed of a thin outer coating of chocolate and an inner filling of tÃºrÃ³ (curd). The "Rudi" in the product name comes from the Hungarian "rÃºd", which translates to rod or bar (and is also a nickname for the name Rudolf). TÃºrÃ³ Rudi can be made in different flavors and sizes.

Name: Sport szelet
Description: A chocolate bar produced in Hungary in the 1950s. It has a dark chocolate coating and an inner filling of rum.

Name: Negro
Description: A Hungarian candy, its black color is derived from molasses, and menthol is used to add flavor. Its full recipe is an industrial secret.[18][19]

Name: Szaloncukor
Description: Christmas candy made of fondant, covered by chocolate, and wrapped in shiny coloured foil

Name: Akanes
Description: Akanes is a Greek sweet similar to loukoumi, only that it is flavoured with fresh butter from buffalo rather than fruit essences.

Name: Fraise Tagada
Description: Invented in 1969 by the Haribo Company, which invented the gummy bear. The Fraise Tagada is presented in the shape of an inflated strawberry covered in fine sugar, colored pink and scented. In France, the Fraise Tagada is one of the most widely sold candies (1 billion Fraises annually) and also one of the most imitated.

Name: Gummi bears
Description: Gelatin based, chewy, fruit flavored

Name: Gummi worms
Description: Gelatin based, chewy, fruit flavored

Name: Milka
Description: A milk chocolate candy that was first created in 1901. The candy's packaging is unique and includes its iconic lilac-colored cow, which helps tie the candy back to its Alpine heritage.[17]

Name: Nappo
Description: A diamond-shaped, chocolate-covered nougat produced in Germany since 1925.

Name: Maoam
Description: Rectangular fruit-flavoured chewy toffee candies.

Name: Churchkhela
Description: Candle-shaped candy made of grape must, nuts and flour.

Name: Bergamote de Nancy
Description: Shiny, small candy squares made from sugar and bergamot essential oil.

Name: Cachou Lajaunie
Description: Hard licorice candies with mint extract.

Name: Calisson
Description: This traditional French candy consists of a smooth, pale yellow, homogeneous paste of candied fruit (especially melons and oranges) and ground almonds topped with a thin layer of royal icing. The calisson is believed to have its origins in medieval Italy.

Name: Carambar
Description: A chewy caramel candy. In 1972, the name changed to "Super Caram'bar". In 1977, the name lost its apostrophe.

Name: Chocolate truffle
Description: The chocolate truffle is thought to have been first created by N. Petruccelli in ChambÃ©ry, France in December 1895.[15] They are traditionally made with a chocolate ganache centre coated in chocolate, icing sugar, cocoa powder or chopped toasted nuts (typically hazelnuts, almonds or coconut), usually in a spherical, conical, or curved shape.

Name: Coucougnette
Description: Confection made with almonds, marzipan, and chocolate.

Name: Hollywood
Description: The first French chewing gum, it was created in 1952. The French were introduced to chewing gum for the first time by the American troops stationed there in 1944. In 1958, the gum's main advertising focus was that of the American Dream. While Hollywood now offers a variety of different flavors, the very first flavor was spearmint.[16]

Name: Macaron
Description: A sweet meringue-based cookie sandwich, with ganache, jam, or buttercream, between two halves. Traditionally believed to have been introduced to France by the Italian chef of queen Catherine De Medici during the Renaissance period.

Name: Marron glacÃ©
Description: A marron glacÃ© (plural marrons glacÃ©s) is a confection, originating in southern France and northern Italy consisting of a chestnut candied in sugar syrup and glazed. Marrons glacÃ©s are an ingredient in many desserts and are also eaten on their own.

Name: Vichy Pastilles
Description: a French confectionery produced in the town of Vichy, department of Allier, France. They were invented in 1825.

Name: Salmiakki
Description: Salty liquorice, is a variety of liquorice flavoured with ammonium chloride, common in the Nordic countries, the Netherlands, and northern Germany.

Name: Geisha
Description: Fazer Geisha is soft milk chocolate contains hazelnut nougat filling.

Name: Dumle
Description: Fazer Dumle is milk chocolate that contains toffee inside it.

Name: Marianne
Description: Fazer Marianne has a hard cover and a chocolate heart inside it.

Name: Turkish Peber
Description: Fazer Tyrkisk Peber has a hard and thick cover and contains salmiakki powder.

Name: London drops
Description: Pastel-coloured liquorice drops with a hard, sugary aniseed-flavoured coating.

Name: Pirate coins
Description: Coin-shaped salty liquorice and fruit flavoured candies with pirate-inspired images.

Name: Finlandia
Description: Spherical fruit-flavoured marmalade candies.

Name: VihreÃ¤t kuulat
Description: Spherical pear-flavoured marmalade candies.

Name: Kiss-Kiss
Description: Oblong pink toffee-filled candies.

Name: Hopeatoffee
Description: Chewy toffee candy bar with a salty liquorice flavour.

Name: Aakkoset
Description: Lozenge-shaped soft, chewy candies in various flavours decorated with capital letters.

Name: Mynthon
Description: Small disc-shaped hard breath mint pastilles.

Name: Manalan makeiset
Description: Hard fruit-flavoured candies containing strong chili extract.

Name: Sisu
Description: Small black chewy, liquorice-flavoured breath mints made with gum arabic.

Name: Dracula Piller
Description: Disc-shaped hard salty liquorice candies.

Name: Kongen af Danmark
Description: Red aniseed-flavoured hard candies containing beetroot juice.

Name: Spunk
Description: Small pastilles with fruit and salty liquorice flavours.

Name: Lokum
Description: Plain or spiced Turkish delight with rose petals, white walnuts, or "endreshe".

Name: Cuberdon
Description: This cone-shaped candy with a melty core and a crisp crust is traditionally flavored with raspberry.

Name: Vanparys
Description: Vanparys manufactures a type of chocolate dragÃ©e: a Belgian dark chocolate, coated with thin layers of sugar, and made in 50 colors in three finishes: matte, glossy, or pearlescent.

Name: Pez
Description: Invented in 1927 in Vienna. Comes in candy refill packs for Pez canisters that comes in a wide variety of famous cartoon characters.

Name: Balikutsa
Description: A sugarcane-based pulled sugar candy from the Ilocos region often used a sweetener for coffee.[8]

Name: Choc Nut
Manufacturer: Unisman and later, Annie's Sweets Manufacturing and Packaging Corporation
Description: A chocolate product that originated in the Philippines and has endured as one of the country's most consumed children's snacks. Called Choc Nut because it is a mixture of powdered peanuts and chocolate.

Name: Flat Tops
Description: A milk chocolate in a circular shape wrapped individually in metallic wrappers.[9]

Name: Hany
Description: Hany milk chocolate is a chocolate mixed with peanuts. It is similar to Choc Nut.[10]

Name: Haw Haw Milk Candy
Description: A rectangular milk powder candy usually sold at many sari-sari stores.[11][12]

Name: Judge
Description: Judge is a chewing gum usually spearmint flavor, there are other flavors such as cherry.[13]

Name: Nata de coco
Description: This chewy, translucent, jelly-like foodstuff is produced by the fermentation of coconut water, which gels through the production of microbial cellulose by Acetobacter xylinum. Originating in the Philippines, nata de coco is most commonly sweetened as a candy or dessert, and can accompany many things including pickles, drinks, ice cream, puddings and fruit mixes.

Name: Potchi
Description: This gummy has a strawberry pink top and white base, it is covered with crystallized sugar to give it more flavor. It's flavor usually is strawberry cream, although it also has a chocolate covered variant.[14]

Name: Dalgona or ppopgi
Description: A Korean sweet candy made from melted sugar and baking soda.

Name: Botan Rice Candy
Description: These chewy rice candies are wrapped in a thin layer of edible rice paper that dissolves in the mouth. A children's sticker is included in every box.

Name: Hi-Chew
Description: This fruit-flavored chewy candy was first released in 1975. It was re-released in its current shape (a stick of several individually wrapped candies) in February 1986. Hi-Chew candies are individually wrapped in logo-stamped foil or plain white wax paper (depending on the localization).

Name: KonpeitÅ
Description: This sugar candy was introduced by the Portuguese in the 16th century, and is a small toffee sphere (5 mm in diameter) with a pimply surface, made from sugar, water, and flour, in a variety of colors. Originally there was a sesame seed in the middle, later a poppy seed, but nowadays no seed at all. The name "konpeito" comes from the Portuguese word "confeito", meaning "confit" (a type of confectionery).

Name: Meiji
Description: Meiji chocolates flavors include cheese, black pepper, jasmine, basil, and lemon salt.[7]

Name: Pocky
Description: This biscuit stick coated with chocolate is also available in a wide variety of other flavors.

Name: Pucca Chocolate
Description: This baked pretzel candy with a chocolate cream center is also available in strawberry and milk flavors.

Name: Puccho
Description: Gummi Puccho squares have a unique consistency similar to a combination of gummy bears and taffy. They often contain gummy "balls" of flavor that are more chewy than the rest of the square. There are also "fizz" balls that mimic the carbonation of their soda derivatives.

Name: Deuk Deuk Tong
Description: Also known as "Ding Ding Tong", it is a hard maltose candy with sesame and ginger flavours.

Name: Dragon's beard candy
Description: Also known as "Chinese cotton candy," it is a handmade traditional art of Ancient China and also a traditional Chinese sweet similar to spun sugar, which can be found in many Chinese communities. The legend of Dragon's Beard Candy was first notably practiced during the Chinese Han Dynasty.[5]

Name: Orange jelly candy
Description: These finger-sized sticks of soft jelly candy are generally sold in food specialty stores in Hong Kong. A great deal of candies available in Hong Kong are imported from Europe, mainland China, United States and other regions around the world. Orange jelly candy is one of the few that have historically been manufactured locally in Hong Kong.

Name: Peen tong
Description: Chinese brown sugar candy.

Name: White Rabbit Creamy Candy
Manufacturer: Shanghai Guan Sheng Yuan Food, Ltd.
Description: This has a soft, chewy texture, and is formed into cylinders approximately 3 cm long and 1 cm in diameter, similar to contemporary western nougat or taffy. Each candy is wrapped in a printed waxed paper wrapper, but within this, the sticky candies are again wrapped in a thin edible paper-like wrapping made from sticky rice.[6] Although the rice wrapping layer is meant to be eaten along with the rest of the candy, it does not figure in the list of ingredients, which is limited to corn starch, syrup, cane sugar, butter, and milk. This also comes in a variety of flavors.

Name: Zaotang
Description: This type of candy is made of maltose that people in China use as a sacrifice to the kitchen god around the twenty third day of the twelfth lunar month just before Chinese New Year.

Name: Haw flakes
Description: It is a sweet, tangy, disc shaped candy made from hawthorn fruit, packaged in a cylindrical paper wrapper.

Name: Astros
Description: A candy coated chocolate with a biscuit center. The product was first launched in 1997 in the United Kingdom, Canada, the United States and in South Africa as a rival to NestlÃ© Smarties, and M&M's in the US.[3] In Australia they were marketed as Lunas.

Name: Massam's
Description: The maker of a nougat candy from South Africa. Varieties include honey almond, almond cherry, and honey cashew. The candies are exported to various countries.
